The tomb proved to be a single-chamber, rock-hewn burial cave; the entrance was blocked, though not tightly sealed, by a partly broken closing stone.

During the late Second Temple period (first century B.C.E.-first century C.E.), more than half of the burial caves around Jerusalem featured finger-like niches cut several feet into the chamber wall; these niches are called kokhim in Hebrew and loculi in Latin.
